Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Investigating Super-Heated Urea for NOx Reduction for Low Temperature Combustion Engine Application

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Nitrogen oxide (NOx) is one of the major pollutants from diesel engines and has its own well-documented health and environmental impacts. Serious efforts have been devoted to reducing them through exhaust clean-up and combustion optimization. Interestingly, there are often trade-offs between efficiency and pollution. This project will develop and demonstrate a greatly improved exhaust after-treatment methodology for NOx reduction, particularly for engines operating at low-temperature combustion regimes. The specific focus will be on developing and testing a novel system for low-cost NOx reduction by super-heating the diesel exhaust fluid (DEF) currently used on diesel engines. The project will not only open up new areas of research, but also directly impact engine combustion and energy efficiency.

NOx has become an important problem because the increased focus on fuel economy has driven engines to burn less fuel and consequently operate at a lower temperature condition. Such low-temperature operations have led to colder exhaust, with hybrid systems that turn the engine on and off only exacerbating this problem. Additionally, the inability to mitigate high levels of NOx has limited the operational window for diesel engines. This project will investigate non-equilibrium NOx reduction through injection of super-heated urea into an engine exhaust stream. Central to this idea is the steep rise of NOx reduction capacities of commercial diesel exhaust fluid (DEF), urea with water, with rising temperature because of higher chemical reaction rates. The new system uses microwave heating of the urea (to 1200 K) prior to injection to make it much more reactive, with experimentally proven NOx reduction of up to 96% for such temperatures in commercial boilers. Experimental testing will be used to measure the exhaust composition for various urea injection cases while computer modeling will be employed to extract the chemical reaction rates that correspond to experimentally observed behaviors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Major pollutants from today’s diesel engines are nitrides of oxygen (NOx), carbon monoxide (CO), particulate matter (PM) and unburned hydrocarbons (UHCs). Each one of these has its own well-documented health and environmental impacts. A common strategy to meet the compliance standards set by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) for these pollutants is the use of a catalytic converter (an expensive catalyst bed) to appropriately reduce or oxidize these pollutants. 

These catalytic converters are crucial for automobiles to stay compliant with the EPA. However, with increased focus on fuel economy, automotive IC engines are being designed to burn decreasing amounts of fuel per cycle and consequently operate at ever colder conditions. The catalyst elements in the catalytic converters, however, needs a high temperature to operate well. This problem has required manufacturers to embark on various redesigns of the catalytic converter, including searching for new, low-temperature catalyst, installing a pre-converter at the piston exhaust port, and other similarly complex and expensive schemes. These difficulties and associated expense have led to the well-publicized emissions cheating scandals of companies like Volkswagen.

This project focused on a short-term, high risk, high reward approach to develop a novel low-cost solution to reduce NOx emissions from diesel engines at all operating conditions. Central to this idea is the steep rise of NOx cleaning capacities of commercial diesel emission fluid (DEF) like Adblue as the temperature rises, because of higher chemical reaction rates as per Arrhenius law. This has also been extensively verified in the related application of using cold urea injections in hot flue gases from furnaces to control their NOx contents, with up to 96% NOx reduction in many systems.

A microwave source from a household microwave oven was used to heat the urea solution through irradiation before it is injected into a NOx-rich environment. Because DEF/Adblue is more than 70% water, it absorbed microwave radiation very well. Also, uniform volumetric heating elevated DEF bulk temperatures to superheated levels without causing phase change, causing better evaporation, mixing and local reaction rates when ultimately introduced into the NOx-rich gas stream.

The results show that superheating the DEF and injecting into hot exhaust decrease NO by 395.3% while room temperature DEF cause only a 248% reduction. This significant improvement can have a positive impact on both pollutant emissions and engine efficiency.
